div.l: (base) Here bigynneth / the knyghtes tale
(base) c incipit fabula Militis ;
(base) Iamque domos patria Scithice post asꝑper/para gentis laurigero etc Here bigynneth the knygtis tale
(base) Whilom / as olde stories tellen vs
(base) Ther was a Duc that highte Theseus
(base) Of Atthenes / he was lord and gouernour
(base) And in his tyme / swich a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Ful many a riche contree / hadde he wonne
(base) What with his wysdom / and his chiualrye
(base) He conquered / al the regne of femenye
(base) That whilom / was ycleped Scithia
(base) And wedded / the queene ypolita
(base) And broghte hire hom with hym / in his contree
(base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
(base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye
(base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh
(base) The remenant of the tale / is long ynogh
(base) I wol nat letten eek / noon of this route
(base) Lat euery felawe / telle his tale aboute
(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
(base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne
(base) Incipit narracio
(base) ¶ Here bygynneth the knyghtes tale.
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten
(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
(base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
(base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town
(base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe
(base) Hath alle the bodyes / on an heep ydrawe
(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neyther to been yburyed / nor ybrent
(base) But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
(base) And with that word / withouten moore respit
(base) They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
(base) Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
(base) And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
(base) Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
(base) That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
(base) And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
(base) Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
(base) That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
(base) As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
(base) And right anoon / withouten moore abood
(base) His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
(base) To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
(base) No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
(base) Ne take his ese / fully half a day
(base) But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
(base) And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
(base) And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
(base) Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
(base) And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
(base) ¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
(base) So shyneth / in his white Baner large
(base) That alle the feeldes / glitren vp and doun
(base) And by his Baner / born was his penoun
(base) Of gold ful ryche / in which ther was ybete
(base) The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete
(base) ¶ Thus ryt this Duc . thus ryt this conquerour
(base) And in his oost of Chiualrye the flour
(base) Forth he rode with grete power and myght
(base) Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
(base) Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte
(base) ¶ But shortly / for to speken of this thyng
(base) With Creoun / which that was of Thebes kyng
(base) He faught and slow hym manly / as a knyght
(base) In pleyn bataille / and putte the folk to flyght
(base) And by assaut he wan the Citee after
(base) And rente adoun / bothe wal / and sparre / and rafter
(base) And to the ladyes / he restored agayn
(base) The bones / of hir freendes / that were slayn
(base) To doon obsequies / as was tho the gyse
(base) But it weere al to long for to deuyse
(base) The grete clamour / and the waymentynge
(base) That the ladyes made / at the brennynge
(base) Of the bodies / and the grete honour
(base) That Theseus / the noble Conquerour
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Dooth to the ladys / whan they from hym wente
(base) But shortly / for to telle is myn entente
(base) ¶ Whan that this worthy duc this Theseus
(base) Hath Creoun slayn / and wonne Thebes thus
(base) Stille in that feeld / he took al nyght his reste
(base) And dide withal the contree / as hym leste
(base) ¶ To ransake in the taas / of bodies dede
(base) Hem for to strepe / of harneys / and of wede
(base) The pilours / diden bisynesse / and cure
(base) After the bataille / and disconfiture
(base) And so bifel / in the taas they founde
(base) Thurgh girt with many a greuous blody wownde
(base) Two yonge knyghtes / liggynge by and by
(base) Bothe in oon armes / wroght ful richely
(base) Of whiche two / Arcita highte that oon
(base) And that oother knyght highte Palamon
(base) Nat fully quyk / ne fully deed they weere
(base) But by hir Cote armures / and by hir geere
(base) The heraudes / knewe hem best in special
(base) As they that weren / of the blood roial
(base) Of Thebes / and of sustren two yborn
(base) Out of the taas / the pilours han hem torn
(base) And han hem caryed / softe vnto the tente
(base) Of Theseus / and he ful soone hem sente
(base) To Atthenes / to dwellen in prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / he nolde no raunsoun
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy duc / hath thus ydoon
(base) He took his oost / and hom he ryt anoon
(base) With laurer corouned / as a conquerour
(base) And there he lyueth / in ioye / and in honour
(base) Terme of his lyf / what nedeth wordes mo
(base) And in a tour / in angwissh and in wo
(base) Dwellen this Palamon / and eek Arcite
(base) For euere moore / ther may no gold hem quyte
(base) ¶ This passeth yeer by yeer / and day by day
(base) Til it fil ones / in a morwe of May
(base) That Emelye / that fairer was to seene
(base) Than is the lilie / vpon his stalke greene
(base) And fressher than the May / with floures newe
(base) For with the Rose colour stroof hir hewe
(base) I noot which was / the fairer of hem two
(base) Er it were day / as was hir wone to do
(base) She was arysen / and al redy dight
(base) For May wol haue / no slogardye a nyght
(base) The sesoun pryketh / euery gentil herte
(base) And maketh it out of his sleep to sterte
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And seith arys / and do thyn obseruance
(base) This maketh Emelye / haue remembrance
(base) To doon honour to May / and for to ryse
(base) Yclothed was she fressh / for to deuyse
(base) Hir yelow heer / was broyded in a tresse
(base) Bihynde hir bak a yerde long I gesse
(base) And in the gardyn / at the sonne vp riste
(base) She walketh vp and doun / and as hir liste
(base) She gadreth floures / party white and rede
(base) To make / a subtil gerland for hir hede
(base) And as an Aungel / heuenysshly she soong
(base) ¶ The grete tour / that was so thikke and strong
(base) Which of the Castel / was the chief dongeoun
(base) Ther as the knyghtes / weren in prisoun
(base) Of whiche I tolde yow / and tellen shal
(base) Was euene ioynant to the gardyn wal
(base) Ther as this Emelye / hadde hir pleyyng
(base) Bright was the sonne / and cleer / in that mornyng
(base) And Palamon / this woful prisoner
(base) As was his wone / by leue of his Gailler
(base) Was risen / and romed in a chambre anheigh
(base) In which / he al the noble Citee seigh
(base) And eek the gardyn / ful of braunches greene
(base) Ther as / the fresshe Emelye the sheene
(base) Was in hir walk / and romed vp and down
(base) This sorweful prisoner / this Palamoun
(base) This wooful louere this Palamon
(base) Gooth in the chambre / romyng to and fro
(base) And to hymself / compleynyng of his wo
(base) That he was born / ful ofte he seyde allas
(base) And so bifel / by auenture / or cas
(base) That thurgh a wyndow / thikke of many a barre
(base) Of Iren greet and square as any sparre
(base) He caste his eye / vpon Emelya
(base) And therwithal he bleynte / and cryde . A .
(base) As thogh / he stongen weere / vnto the herte
(base) ¶ And with that cry / Arcite anoon vp sterte
(base) And seyde cosyn myn / what eyleth thee
(base) That art so pale / and deedly on to see
(base) Why cridestow / who hath thee doon offence
(base) For goddes loue / tak al in pacience
(base) Oure prison / for it may noon oother be
(base) Fortune / hath yeuen vs this aduersitee
(base) Som wikked aspect or disposicioun
(base) Of Saturne / by som constellacioun
(base) Hath yeuen vs this / althogh we hadde it sworn
(base) So stood the heuene / whan that we were born
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) We mote endure it this is the short and playn
(base) This Palamoun answerde / and seyde agayn
(base) ¶ Cosyn for sothe / of this opinioun
(base) Thow hast a vayn ymaginacioun
(base) This prisoun / caused me noght to crye
(base) But I was hurt right now / thurgh out myn Iye
(base) In to myn herte / that wol my bane be
(base) The fairnesse / of that lady that I se
(base) Yond in the gardyn / romen to and fro
(base) Is cause / of al my cryyng and my wo
(base) I noot wher she be womman / or goddesse
(base) But Venus / is it soothly / as I gesse
(base) And therwithal / on knees down he fil
(base) And seyde / Venus if it be thy wil
(base) Yow in this gardyn / thus to transfigure
(base) Bifore me / sorweful wrecched creature
(base) Out of this prisoun / help that we may scape
(base) And if so be / my destynee be shape
(base) By eterne word / to dyen in prisoun
(base) Of oure lynage / haue som compassioun
(base) That is so lowe ybroght by tirannye
(base) ¶ And with that word / Arcite gan espye
(base) Where as this lady / romed to and fro
(base) And with that sighte / hir beautee hurte hym so
(base) That if that Palamon / was wounded soore
(base) Arcite is hurt . as muche as he / or moore
(base) And with a syk / . he seyde pitously
(base) The fresshe beautee / sleeth me sodeynly
(base) Of hire / that rometh in the yonder place
(base) And but I haue / hir mercy / and hir grace
(base) That I may seen hire / at the leeste weye
(base) I nam but deed / ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ This Palamon / whan he tho wordes herde
(base) Despitously / he loked / and answerde
(base) Wheither seistow this / in ernest or in pley
(base) ¶ Nay quod Arcite / in ernest by my fey
(base) God help me so / me list ful yuele pleye
(base) This Palamon / gan knytte his browes tweye
(base) ¶ It were to thee quod he / no greet honour
(base) For to be fals / ne for to be traytour
(base) To me / that am thy cosyn and thy brother
(base) Ysworn ful depe / and ech of vs til oother
(base) That neuere / for to dyen in the peyne
(base) Til that the deeth / departe shal vs tweyne
(base) Neither of vs / in loue to hyndre oother
(base) Ne in noon oother caas / my leeue brother
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But that thow sholdest trewely forthre me
(base) In euery caas / as I shal forthren thee
(base) This was thyn ooth / and myn also certeyn
(base) I woot right wel / thow darst it nat withseyn
(base) Thus artow of my conseil / out of doute
(base) And now / thow woldest falsly been aboute
(base) To loue my lady / whom I loue and serue
(base) And euere shal / til that myn herte sterue
(base) Now certes false Arcite / thow shalt nat so
(base) I loued hire first and tolde thee my wo
(base) As to my conseil / and my brother sworn
(base) To forthre me / as I haue told biforn
(base) For which / thow art ybounden / as a knyght
(base) To helpe me / if it laye in thy myght
(base) Or ellis artow fals / I dar wel sayn
(base) This Arcite / ful proudly spak agayn
(base) ¶ Thow shalt quod he / be rather fals than I
(base) And thow art fals / I telle thee outrely
(base) For paramour / I loued hire first er thow
(base) What wiltow seyn / thow woost nat yet now
(base) Wheither she be a womman / or goddesse
(base) Thyn is / affeccioun of holynesse
(base) And myn is loue / as to a creature
(base) For which / I tolde thee myn auenture
(base) As to my cosyn / and my brother sworn
(base) I pose / that thow louedest hire biforn
(base) Wostow nat wel / the olde clerkes sawe
(base) That who shal / yeue a louere any lawe
(base) Quis / legem det amantibz
(base) Loue is a gretter lawe / by my pan
(base) Than may be yeue / to any erthely man
(base) And therfore / posityf lawe / and swich decree
(base) Is broke alday for loue / in ech degree
(base) A man moot nedes loue / maugree his heed
(base) He may nat fleen it / thogh he sholde be deed
(base) Al be she mayde / wydwe / or ellis wyf
(base) And eek it is nat likly / al thy lyf
(base) To stonden in hir grace / namoore shal I
(base) For wel thow woost thy self verraily
(base) That thow and I / been dampned to prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / vs gayneth no raunsoun
(base) We stryue / as dide the houndes / for the boon
(base) They foghte alday / and yet hir part was noon
(base) Ther cam a kyte / whil that they were so wrothe
(base) That bar awey the boon / bitwix hem bothe
(base) And therfore / at the kynges court my brother
(base) Ech man for hymself / ther is noon oother
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Loue if thee lest . for I loue / and ay shal
(base) And soothly / leue brother this is al
(base) Heere in this prisoun / moote we endure
(base) And euerich of vs / take his auenture
(base) ¶ Greet was the stryf / and long bitwix hem tweye
(base) If that I hadde leyser for to seye
(base) But to theffect it happed on a day
(base) To telle it yow / as shortly as I may
(base) A worthy duc . that highte Parotheus
(base) That felawe was / vnto Duc Theseus
(base) Syn thilke day / that they were children lyte
(base) Was come to Atthenes / his felawe to visite
(base) And for to pleye / as he was wont to do
(base) For in this world / he loued no man so
(base) And he loued hym / as tendrely agayn
(base) So wel they loued / as olde bookes sayn
(base) That whan that oon was deed / soothly to telle
(base) His felawe wente / and soghte hym down in helle
(base) But of that storie / list me noght to write
(base) Duc Parotheus / loued wel Arcite
(base) And hadde hym knowe at Thebes / yeer by yere
(base) And finally / at requeste and prayere
(base) Of Parotheus / withouten any raunsoun
(base) Duc Theseus / hym leet out of prisoun
(base) Frely to goon / wher that hym liste oueral
(base) In swich a gyse / as I yow tellen shal
(base) This was the forward / pleynly for tendite
(base) Bitwixe Theseus / and hym Arcite
(base) That if so weere that Arcite weere yfounde
(base) Euere in his lyf by day / or nyght or stounde
(base) In any contree / of this Theseus
(base) And he weere caught . it was acorded thus
(base) That with a swerd / he sholde lese his heed
(base) Ther nas noon oother / remedye ne reed
(base) But taketh his leue / and homward he hym spedde
(base) Lat hym be war / his nekke lyth to wedde
(base) Hit were a gret thing to telle and to wite
(base) ¶ How greet a sorwe / suffreth now Arcite
(base) The deeth he feeleth / thurgh his herte smyte
(base) He wepeth / wayleth / cryeth pitously
(base) To sleen hymself he wayteth pryuely
(base) He seyde allas / the day that I was born
(base) Now is my prisoun / worse than biforn
(base) Now is me shape / eternally to dwelle
(base) Noght in purgatorie / but in helle
(base) Allas / that euere knew I Parotheus
(base) For ellis / hadde I dwelled with Theseus
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Yfettred in his prisoun eueremo
(base) Thanne hadde I been in blisse / and nat in wo
(base) Oonly the sighte of hire / whom that I serue
(base) Thogh that I neuere / hir grace may disserue
(base) Wolde haue suffised / right ynogh for me
(base) ¶ O deere cosyn / Palamon / quod he
(base) Thyn is the victorie / of this auenture
(base) Ful blisfully / in prisoun maystow dure
(base) In prison ; / nay certes / but in paradys
(base) Wel hath Fortune / yturned thee / the dys
(base) That hast the sighte of hire / and I thabsence
(base) For possible is / syn thow hast hire presence
(base) And art a knyght a worthy and an able
(base) That by som caas / syn Fortune is chaungeable
(base) Thow mayst to thy desir / som tyme atteyne
(base) But I / that am exiled and bareyne

(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne

div.l: (base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
(base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght
(base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord
(base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale

div.l: There is at the west side of Italie
Down at the roote of vesulus the cold
A lustie playne abundant of vitail
Wher many a tovne and toure thou maist behold
That foundet wer in tyme of fadres old
And many an othre delectable sight
And Salıı̄unce this noble contree hight
A Marquis whilom was in that lond
As was his othir worthie eldres him beforn
And obeissaunt ay redie to his hond
Wer al his liegges both les and more
Thus in delite he reigned and has doon yore
Beloved and drede thurgh favoure and fortune
Both of his lordes and of his cōmmune
Therwith he was as to speke of lynage
The Ientillest I born of al Lumbardie
A fair ꝑper/parsoıı̄un and strong and yong of age
And ful of honour and of curtesie
Discrete enugh his countree for to gye
Save in some thinges he was to blame
And Walter was this yong mans name
I blamed him thus that he considred noght
In tyme comyng what might hym betide
Bot on his lust present was al his thoght
And forto havke and hunt on eủer/rey side
Wel nigh al othre cures lete he slide
And eke he ne wold and that was the dearst of al
Wedd no wyfe for oght that might befal
Oonly that poynt his people bare so sore
That flok meel opon a day they to him went
And oon of theim that wisest was of lore
Or elles that the lorde wold best assent
That he shuld tel him what the people ment
Or elles covth he wel shew such matier
He to the Marquis said as ye may here
O noble Marquis youre humanitee
Assureth vs and gyf vs hardynes
As oft tyme as it is of necessitee
That we you mow tel oure hevines
Accepteth lord of youre Ientillnes
That we to you with pitous hert compleyn
And let youre eres not my voice disdeyn
Al have I noght to doon in this matier
More than an othre man hath in this place
Yit for as moche as ye my lord so dere
Have al way shewed me favour and grace
I dar the bettir ask of you a space
Of audience to shewen our request
And ye my lorde to doon right as you list
For certes lorde so wele vs liketh you
And al youres and eủer/re have doon that we
Ne covth noght oure own self devisen how
We might more life in felicite
Save oon thing lord if youre wil be
That forto be a wedded man if you list
Than wer your people in soủer/reyan hertes rest
Boweth youre nek vndre that blisful yoke
Of soủer/reyantie and noght of suice
Which men cal spousal or wedloke
And thinketh lord among youre thoghtes wyse
That of wedlok comes grete Emprice
For thogh we slepe or wake or ron or ride
Ay fleeth the tyme it wolle nooman abide
And to al your grene youth grow as yitt
In crepeth age allway as stil as a stoon
And deth manassheth eủer/rey age and smyte
In ych astate for him escapeth noon
And also certayn as we know eủer/reychoon
That we shul die and vncertayn that we al
Ben of that day that deth shal on vs fal
Accepteth than of vs the true entent
That non yit refuseth youre hest
And we wollen al lord if ye wolle assent
Chese you a wife in short tyme at the best
Born of the ientillest and of the most
Of al this lond. so that it oght seme
Honoure to god and yov ~ so as we can deme
Delyver vs of al this busie drede
And take a wyfe for hie goddes sake
For if it befel so. as god forbede
That thurgh youre deth yoᵘur linage shuld a slake
And a straunge linage shuld take
Youre heritage woo wer vs than on lyve
Wherfore we pray you hastely to wyve
Wheir meke prayer and their pitous chere
Made the Marquis have such pitee
Wolle ye qd he myn own people dere
To that I neủer/re erst thogh me
Than I me reioys not of my libertee
That sheeld tyme is fond mariage
Ther I was free I must be in suage
But nathles I se your trew entent
And trust vpon you and have doo ay
Wherfore of my free wil I assent
To wed me as sone as eủer/re I may
Bot ther as ye have ꝓprofered me to day
To chese me a wyfe I you relesse
Of that chose and of that ꝓprofre I pᵃy you to cesse
For god it wot that childeren oft ben
Vnlike their worthie eldres theim beforn
Bounte cometh al of god and not of the streen
Of which they ben engendred and born
I trust in goddes bounte and therforn
My mariage and myn estate and rest
I him betake he may doo as him lest
Lett me alloon in chesing of my wyfe
That charge vpon my bak I wil endure
Bot I yov pray and charge vpon your life
That wife that I take ye me ensure
To worshipp hir while my life endure
In word in wark both here and elles wher
As she an Emꝑper/paroures doght ̉er/re were
And ferthirmore this shal ye swere that ye
Agayn my chose shal navthre gruche ne strife
For sith I shal forgoo my libertee
At youre request so eủer/re mot I thryve
Ther as myn hert is sett ther wil I wyve
And bot ye wolle assent in such manere
I pray yov speke nomore of this matier
With herthe wil the sworen and assenten
To al this thing ther said noo wight nay
Beseching him of grace or they wenten
That he theim wold graunt a certayn day
Of his spovsai as sone as eủer/re he may
For yit allway the people sum what dred
Lest this Marquis wold noo wife wed
He graunted theim a day such as him lest
On which he wold be wedded sicurly
And said he did al this at their request
And they with humble entent ful buxomly
Kneled vpon their knees ful reủer/reently
They thanked him al and thus they have an ende
Of their entent and then they haue home wende
And hervpon he to his officers
Commaunding for the fest to purvey
And to his privey knightes and squyers
Such charge gave them as him list on theim lay
And they to his commaundmentz obey
And ich of them dooth his diligence
To doon vnto the fest Reủer/reence
Noght far from thilk place honorable
Wher as this Marquis shope his mariage
Ther stoode a thorp of sight delectable
In which poer folk of that village
Had their bestes and their herboᵘurgage
And of their laboure toke their sustinaunce
Aftir the erth gave theim abundaunce
Among this poer folk ther dwelled a man
Which that was holden porest of them al
Bot hie god sum tyme send can
His grace vnto a litle ox stal
Ianicula men of that thorp him cal
A doght ̉er/re had he faire and yong in sight
And Gseld this yong maydyn hight
Bot for to speke of vertuous beuatie
Than was she oon vndre the sonne
Ful porely broght vp was she
No licouresnes in hir hert was ronne
Wele oft of the wel than of the tonne
She drank and for she wold vertue please
She knew wel laboure bot noon wel ease
Bot thogh this made wer tendre and yong of age
Yit in the breste of hir virginite
Ther was enclosed ripe and sad corage
And in grete reủer/reence and grete charite
His old poer fadre fostred she
A few shepe spynnyng on the feld she kept
She wold not ben Idel but when she slept
And whan she homeward come she wold bring
Wortes and herbes tyme ful oft
Which she shrad and seeth for hir lyving
And made hir bed hard and noothing soft
And ay she kept hir fadre life on loft
With eủer/rey obeisaunce and diligence
That child may doo to fadres reủer/reence
Vpon Griseld the poer creature
Wele oft hath Marquis set his eie
As he on hunting rode ꝑper/paraventure
And whan it fel that he might hir asspie
He noght with wanton loking of folie
His eien cast vpon hir bot in sad wise
Vpon hir chere he wold him oft avise
Commending in his hert hir womanhede
And eke hir vertue passing eủer/rey wight
Of so yong age as wele in chere as in dede
For thogh the people have noo grete in sight
In vertue he considreth ful right
Hir beuautie . and disposed that he wold
Hir wed if eủer/re he wedd shold
The day of wedding come bot noo wight can
Tell what woman it shuld be
For which mvail woundred many a man
And said when they wer in privetee
Wolle not oure lorde leve his vanitee
Wolle he noght wed allas allas the while
Whi wolle he him self and vs thus begyle
Bot nathles this Marquis hath doo make
Of gemmes set in gold and asure
Broches and ringes for Griseld sake
And of hir clothing toke he the mesure
Of a maiden like to hir stature
And eke of othre ornamentz also
That to suche a wedding shulde fal
The tyme of vndren of the same day
Approched that this wedding shuld be
And al the paleys put was in aray
Both hal and chambre ich in his degree
Houses of office stuffed with grete plentee
Ther maist thou see of dayntevous vitaile
That may be found as far as Italie
This royal Marquis rially arrayd
Lordes and ladies in his companye
The which to the fest wer prayd
And of retenue his bachillarie
With many a sown of sondrie melodie
Vnto the vilage of which I told
In this array the right way they hold
Griseld of this god wote ful Innocent
Therfore hir was shape al this array
To fecchen wat ̉er/re to the wel is went
And comes home as sone as eủer/re she may
For wele she hard herd say that ilk day
That Marquis shuld wed and if she might
She wold fayn se some of that sight
She thoght I wolle with othr madyns stond
That ben my fellays in our dore and se
This Marquis and therfor wolle I found
To doon at home as sone as it may be
The laboᵘur which that longeth to me
And than may I at layser it behold
If she this day vnto the castel hold
And as she wold oủer/re the threscefold goon
This Marquis come and gan hir forto cal
And she set down hir wat ̉er/re pot anoon
Byside the threscefold of the ox stal
And down vpon hir knees she gan to fal
And with said countenaunce kneled stil
Til she had herd what was the lordes wil
This thoghtful Marquis spake vnto this maide
Wele soburlie and said in this maner
Wher is youre fadre griseld he said
And she with reủer/reence and meke cher
Answerd ; lord he is al redie here
And in she gooth withouten leng lett
And to the Marquis she hir fadre fett
He by the hond toke this old man
And said thus whan he him had on side
Ianicula ; I neủer/re may ne can
Leng the pleasaunce of myn hert hide
If that ye vouchesave what so betide
Thy doghtre wolle I take or that I wende
As for my wife to my lives ende
Thov lovest me I wote wele c̉er/retayn
And art my faithful liegge man I bore
And al that liketh me I dar wele sayn
Iit liketh me and speciallie therfore
Tel me that poynt that I have said before
If that thov wol vnto that purpos draw
To take me as for thi son in law
The sodan case the man astonned soo
That reid he wax al basshed ⁊and al quaking
He stoode ne vnneth said he wordes moo
But oonlie thus lord qd he my willing
Is as ye wolle ; noght agayns youre liking
I wolle noo thing ; ye be my lord so dere
Right as yov list. governeth ye this matier
Than wolle I doo this qd Marquis sotilly
That in thin chaumbre I and thov and she
Have a collaciou and wost thov why
For I wil ask hir if hir wil be
To be my wife and reule hir aft ̉er/re me
And al this she shal doon in thy psence
I wolle not speke oute of thyn audience
And in the chaumbre while they wer aboute
Their tretys which ye shul aftir here
The people come into the hous withoute
And wonndred theim in how honest manere
And tentiflie she kept hir fadre dere
Bot vttirlie Griseld woundre might
For neủer/re erst saw she such a sight
Noo woundre is thogh she be a stouned
To see so grete a gest come in to that place
She was neủer/re to such gestes wouned
For which she loked with ful pale face
Bot shortlie forth this matier forto chace
Thes wer the wordes that this Marquis said
To this benigne verray faithful maid
Griseld he said ye wolle wele vndrestond
It liketh vnto youre fadre and to me
That I you wedd and eke it may so stond
As I suppos that ye wolle that it so be
Bot this demaund I ax first qd he
That sithen it shal be doon on hasty wise
Wolle ye assent therto or yow avise
I say this be ye redie with goode hertt
Til al my list and that I frelie may
As me best thinketh doo you laugh or smert
And yeuen grucche night ne day
And eke whan I say ya say ye not nay
Neithir be word ne froward countenᵃnce
Swere thus and her I swere our alliaunce
Wondring vpon this word quaking for drede
She said vndigne and also vnworthyie
Am I to that. that ye me bede
Bot right as ye wolle youre self so wolle I
And I swere that neủer/re willingly
In word nor in thoght I neủer/re you disobeye
Forto be deid thogh me wer loth to die
This is enugh Griseld myn qd he
And forth he gooth with a sobre chere
Oute at the dore and aftir come she
And to the people he said on this maner
This is my wife qd he that stoundes here
Honoure hir and lufe hir I you pray
Who so loveth me ther is nomore to say
And for nothing of hir old gere
She shuld bring to his hous he bad
That women shuld spoilen hers right ther
Of which the ladies wer not right glad
To handel hir clothes in which she was clad
But nathles this maide bright of hew
Fro fote to heid they clothed haue al new
Hir here haue they kembed that lay vntressed
That she endured al hir adủer/resitee
And to the Sergeant mekelie she saide
Have her agayn this litle yong maide
And gooth now qd she and doo my lordes heest
And o thing wold I pray yov of youre grace
That bot my lord forbede you at leest
Berieth this litle bodie in sum place
That no bestes no birdes it to race
Bot he noo word to that purpos wold say
Bot toke the child and went on his way
This seriaunt come to the lorde agayn
And of Griseld wordes and of hir chere
He told him poynt be poynt in short and playn
And him psented with his doghtre dere
Some what this lord had ruth in his maner
But nathles his purpos held he styl
As lordes doon whan they wol have their wil
And bad this sergiaunt ful prdvelie
He wold wele soft this child wynd and wrapp
With al circumcistaunce tendrelyie
And carie it in a coffre or in a lapp
Bot of payn of his heid of to swapp
That noo man shuld know of his entent
Ne whens he come ne whethre that he went
Bot at Boloyn xx to his sustre dere
That thoo tyme of pavy was countesse
He shuld it take and shew hir this matere
Bisekynge hire to doon hir busynes
This child to foster in al gladnes
And whoos child that it was he bad hir hide
From eủer/rey wight for oght that might betide
This seriaunt gooth and fulfilled this thing
Bot to the Marquis now retorne we
For now gooth he wel oft ymagynyng
If by his wife he might see
And by hir wordes ꝑper/parsaive that she
Wer chaunged ; bot he covth neủer/re fynde
Bot eủer/re in oon elike sad and kynde
As glad as humble as besie in suice
And eke in luf as she was won to be
Was she to him on eủer/re man wise
Ne of hir doght ̉er/re a worde spake she
Non accident for noon adủer/resitee
Was seen in hir ne neủer/re r doght ̉er/re name
Named she in ernest nor in game
In this estate passed ben foure yere
Er she with childe was bot as god wold
A knave child she bare by this Waltere
Wele graciuslie . and faire to behold
And whan folk it to his fadre told
Not oonlie he bot al the contre merie
Was for that childe. and god they thank and marie
Whan that it was twoo yer old. and fro the brest
Departed from his nors on a day
This Marquis toke yit an othre lest
To temp his wife often if he may
Of nedles was she tempted in assay
Bot wedded men knowen noo mesure
Whan they fynd a pacient creature
Wyfe qd this Marquis ye have herd of this
My people sekely bereth oure mariage
And namely sithen my son born is
Now is it wors than eủer/re in oure age
The murmure sleeth myn hert and my corage
For to myn eres cometh the voice so smert
That il wellnye hath destroyed al myn hert
Now saye men thus whan Waltere is agoon
Than shal the bloode of Ianicle succede
And ben oure lorde for othre have we noone
Such wordes sayn my people it is noo drede
Wele ought I of such mʳmʳ take hede
For certanlie I drede such sentence
Thogh they not pleynly speke in myn audience
I wold life in peace if that I might
Wherfore I am disposed vttrilie
As I his sustre served be night
Right so I think to serve him pvelie
Thus warn I yow that ye not sodanlie
Oute of youre self for noo woo shuld outray
Be pacient and therof I you pray
I have qd she said and eủer/re shal
I wolle desire noo man thing certayn
Bot as you lest it greves me not at al
Thogh that my doght ̉er/re and my son be slayn
At youre cōmmaundment that is to sayn
I have had part of children twayn
Bot first sekenes and aft ̉er/re woo and payn
Ye ben oure lorde doo with youre own thing
Right as you list and askes noo reid of me
For as I left at home al my clothing
Whan I come furst to you right so qd she
Left I my wil and al my libertee
And toke youre clothing wherfore I you pray
Doo youre wil I wolle to it obeye
And certes if I had pscience
Youre wol to know as ye youre lest me told
I wold it doon withoute negligence
Bot now I wot youre lust and what ye wold
Al your plesaunce ferme and stable I hold
For wist I that my deth wold doo you eas
Gladly wold I suffre it you to pleas
Deth may make noo comparisoıı̄un
Vnto youre luf and whan this Marquis say
The constance of his wife. his heid a don
And his eien twoo ; and wondred how she may
In such penᵃnce suffre al this array
And furth he gooth with drery countenᵃnce
Bot to his hert it was ful grete plesnᵃnce
This egle sergeant in the same wise
That hir doghtre caght right so he
Or wers if he covth wors devise
He caght hir childe that ful was of beuatie
And eủer/re in oon so pacient was she
That she noo chere made of hevynes
Bot blissed hir son and aft ̉er/re can him kys
Save this she prayd him if that he might
Hir litle sonne he wold in erth grave
His tendre lymmes tendre vnto sight
From bestes and from fulles to save
Bot she noon answer of him might have
He went his way as he nothing roght
Bot into Boloyn tendirlie he broght
This Marquis eủer/re leng more
Vpon hir pacience and if that he
Ne had knowe sothlie therbefore
That ꝑper/parfitlie hir children lufed she
He wold a wend that of sume sotelte
And of malice and of cruel corage
That she had suffred this with sad visage
Bot he knewe that next him self certayn
She lufed hir children best on eủer/rey wise
Bot now of women wold I ask fayn
If thes assayes might noght suffice
What couth a sturdie husbond device
To preve hir wifehode and hir stedfastnes
And he contynving in sturdynes
But ther ben folk of suche condicioıı̄un
That whan they have a certayn purpos take
They cun not stynt of their entenciou
Bot as they wer bounden vnto a stake
They wil noght of their purpos slake
Right so this Marquis hath fully purposed
To tempe his wife as he was furst disposed
He wateth if by word or countenaunce
If she to him was chaunged of corage
Bot neủer/re covth he fynde variance
She was eủer/re in hert and in visage
And eủer/re the farther that she was in age
The more // if it wer possible // trewth
She was to him in luf and more plessible
For which it semeth thus that of them twoo
Ther was bot oon wil . for as Walter lest
The same list was hir plesᵃunce also
And god be thonked al fel for the best
She shewed wele for noo worldly vnrest
A wife as of hir self nothing shold
Wil in effecte bot as hir husbond wold
The slaundre of Walter oft wide sprad
That of a cruel hert wikkedly
For he a poer woman wedded had
Has murthred both his childre pdvely
Which murmur was emong them comonly
No wonndre was for to the people ere
Ther come noo worde bot that they murthred wer
For suche as of his people ther before
Had lufed him wel disclaundre of his name
Made theym that they hated him therfore
To ben a murtheror is an hateful name
Bot natheles for ernest no for game
He of his crueltie not wold stynt
To temp his wife was al his entent
Whan this doghtre twelf yer was of age
He to the courte of rome in sothlie wise
Enfourmed of his wil sent his message
Commaunding theym such bulles to devise
As to his cruel purpos may suffice
How that the pope as for his puple rest
Bad him wed an othr if him lest
I say he bad they shuld count̉er/refete
The popes bulles making mensioıı̄un
That he has leif his furst lif to lete
As by the Pope dispensacioıı̄un
To stynt rancoᵘur and discencioıı̄un
Be twix the people and him thus spake the bul
The which they have publesshed at the ful
The rude people as noo wondre is
Wend ful wel it had ben soo
Bot whan thus tithandes come to Grisildis
I deme that hir hert was ful of woo
Bot she was elike sad eủer/remoo
Disposed was this humble creature
The adủer/resite of fortune al forto endure
Abiding eủer/re his list and his plasaunce
To whome she was gyven body hert and al
As to hir worldly suffisaunce
For certanlie soth is storie tell I shal
This Marquis hath in esspecial
Wretyn a lre wherin he shewed his entent
And securly he to Boleyn he it sent
To the Erle of Pavy which that had thoo
